title: 108_s2035
content:
The Act titled "Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004" allows eligibility for retired pay for non-regular service. The Act "Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004" amends age and service requirements for retired pay eligibility under title 10, United States Code. The Act "Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004" amends age and service requirements for retired pay eligibility under title 10, United States Code. Before October 5, 1994, the number of years of qualifying service for retired pay eligibility is eight. The minimum age and years of service combinations required for retired pay entitlement are specified. The Act "Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004" changes the age and service requirements for retired pay eligibility under title 10, United States Code. The minimum age and years of service combinations needed for retired pay entitlement are specified as follows: 53 years - 34 years of service, 54 years - 32 years of service, 55 years - 30 years of service, 56 years - 28 years of service, 57 years - 26 years of service, 58 years - 24 years of service, 59 years - 22 years of service, and 60 years - 20 years of service. Additionally, the 20-Year Letter is amended to require 20 years of service computed under section 12732 of this title. The amendments made by the Guard and Reserve Readiness and Retention Act of 2004 change the age and service requirements for retired pay eligibility under title 10, United States Code. The effective date for these changes is the first day of the first month after the enactment of the Act, applying to retired pay payable for that month and subsequent months. SEC. 3. Expanded eligibility of Ready Reserve members under TRICARE program. Amends eligibility criteria for TRICARE benefits for Ready Reserve members. Repeals permanent authority and removes obsolete provisions.

SEC. 4. Continuation of non-TRICARE health benefits plan coverage for certain reserves called or ordered to active duty and their dependents. Allows certain reserves called to active duty to continue non-TRICARE health benefits plan coverage for themselves and their dependents. The new section 1078b of Chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, allows the Secretary concerned to pay the premium for qualified health benefits plan coverage for family members of eligible reserve component members called to active duty. Eligibility is based on serving on active duty pursuant to a call or order. The new section 1078b of Chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code allows the Secretary to pay for health benefits plan coverage for family members of eligible reserve component members called to active duty during a war or national emergency. The coverage must be in force on the date of notification of the call or order. The new section 1078b of Chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code allows the Secretary to pay for health benefits plan coverage for family members of eligible reserve component members called to active duty during a war or national emergency. The coverage must be in force on the date of notification of the call or order. The applicable premium payable for continuation of health benefits plan coverage for family members is based on the member's premium amount. The total amount the Department of Defense may pay for the premium in a fiscal year is calculated based on the number of family members covered. The benefits coverage continuation period for family members of eligible reserve component members called to active duty is determined by the Secretary of Defense. It begins on the date of the call or order and ends when the reserve component member's eligibility for transitional health care terminates. The COBRA coverage period for eligible reserve component members can be extended, with rules similar to those under section 4980B(f)(5)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applying. The COBRA coverage period for eligible reserve component members can be extended, with rules similar to section 4980B(f)(5)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code applying. Family members of reserve component members receiving benefits under a qualified health benefits plan are not eligible for TRICARE benefits during the coverage period. Reserve component members can revoke their election for benefits, allowing their family members to become eligible for TRICARE benefits. The Secretary of Defense will establish regulations for implementing this section. The Secretary may establish requirements for election of payment of premiums. Amend the table of sections to include a new item after section 1078a. Section 1078b of title 10, United States Code allows for continuation of non-TRICARE health benefits plan coverage for dependents of certain Reserves called to active duty. This applies to calls or orders issued by the Secretary of a military department before, on, or after the enactment of this Act, specifically for qualified health benefits plan coverage in effect at that time.
